sense.name: the act of pressing together firmly
sense.examples: The man threatened to blow his head off with one squeeze of the trigger. Give the sponge a good squeeze before wiping the table with it. The grandmother gave the child a little squeeze on the cheek.

sense.name: a state or circumstance of financial restriction
sense.examples: During a credit squeeze, businesses find it hard to obtain loans. The higher corporate taxes will place a squeeze on profits.

sense.name: a romantic partner, girlfriend or boyfriend
sense.examples: The gossip at work is that Mary is John's new squeeze. The poor guy lost his main squeeze to a rich playboy.

sense.name: an aggressive power play
sense.examples: The offense really put the squeeze on our team during the final quarter. She ignored the boss's squeeze play for her sexual favors.

sense.name: a hug, an embrace
sense.examples: Sally gave her friend a big squeeze when they met at the airport. He meant it as a friendly little squeeze, nothing more.

sense.name: a state of confinement in a small space
sense.examples: It will be quite a squeeze to get seven people in Pete's car. It was a tight squeeze for the crowd in the tiny hall.

sense.name: small approximate amount of liquid
sense.examples: Add a squeeze of lemon juice to the sauce. Just a squeeze of fresh lime adds a nice note to the drink.
